People don t just pick random delivery times because they don t really care when it turns up  i pick times which fit in with my day...i have severe health problems and have to fit things around dealing with that. If i don t answer my phone it is because i am either out or am unable to. Sainsbury s as a store has good reviews  but Sainsbury s Energy is one to avoid. Last October  British Gas recommended Sainsburys Energy as a cheaper tariff as my current tariff was due to end. I contacted SE and received a reply on 18 Oct 2016  to say my energy switch to Sainsburys from British Gas would take 2 weeks. At the beginning of Dec I realised I had heard nothing further from SE so I registered a complaint on SE page and was given a complaint ref. number. I also went onto register the same complaint on British Gas website as they had recommended SE to me. I was surprised to see only a few digits difference between the complaints reference numbers of SE and BG. Then I realised BG and SE are one and the same.  Sainsbury s Energy is a trading name used under licence by British Gas Trading Limited  a Centrica company. Registered in England and Wales No. 3078711 I was told by SE that they had no record of me applying to  change   so I sent them a copy of the email I received from SE in October  and I was told it appeared that the request had been ignored. British Gas are not interested in my problem and have just said to contact SE as it is their fault  even though they are one and the same company and even use the same complaints and computer systems. As a result  BG have put me on the highest tariff possible as my tariff with BG has expired. After an initial response from SE on 7 Dec  I have heard NOTHING  so I am still paying their alter ego British Gas at the highest rate. I have contacted OFGEM  to ask why these so called  white label arrangements   which allow bigger companies such as BG to supply energy to companies who don t hold their own supply licence such as Sainsburys  are allowed at all. Why can t BG offer customers the same rate as their alter ego company? There must be some financial benefit in this for BG  but certainly not for the customer when they wash their hands of any problems encountered by customers in the so called   switch .  I continue to pay BG at the highest rate with no communication from BG or SE since Dec 6 2016. Trading Standards really needs to look at the practices of Big Energy Companies and the scams they appear to be pulling on customers.  It s Trading Standards and OFGEM I will deal with now as I have had enough of Big Business attitudes.

BEING FORCED TO WORK A SUNDAY? An employer has the right  whether or not it is explicitly reflected in the employment contract  to require a worker to work on a public holiday. It is common in industries such as retail or emergency services. We have also heard from hon. Members about other sectors such as hospitality  sport and leisure. Employers can determine when workers take their leave‚Äîfor example  to cover an annual shutdown at work‚Äîand can refuse to give leave at a certain time  but they must give workers the opportunity to take their leave at some point during the leave year. The entitlement should give all workers sufficient time to see their families over the year  although I accept that Christmas and various other times of the year are absolutely associated with spending time with family.  In addition  there are special provisions for shop workers who do not wish to work on Sundays  at least. All shop and betting shop workers can opt out of Sunday working  unless Sunday is the only day they have been employed to work. A shop worker can opt out of Sunday working  even if they agreed in their contract to work on Sundays  by giving three months‚Äô notice.
